articles.headline: Regulators Push Safety Standards for A.T.V.’s
articles.snippet: An influx of faulty Chinese-made all-terrain vehicles is challenging the Consumer Product Safety Commission.
articles.abstract: An influx of faulty Chinese-made all-terrain vehicles is challenging the Consumer Product Safety Commission.
articles.lead_paragraph: For parents wanting to provide their children some good, clean off-roading fun, the Fushin, a smaller-than-normal all-terrain vehicle, seemed just the thing.

articles.headline: Price War Brews Between Amazon and Wal-Mart
articles.snippet: For now, it’s a battle of discounts, but Wal-Mart and Amazon are also fighting over the future of retailing.
articles.abstract: For now, it’s a battle of discounts, but Wal-Mart and Amazon are also fighting over the future of retailing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ali had Frazier. Coke has Pepsi. The Yankees have the Red Sox.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Stephanie Rosenbloom

articles.headline: Start Date Is Critical in Ponzi Plan
articles.snippet: A court motion contends that Bernard L. Madoff’s investors cannot calculate their losses until it is determined whether any of their original profits were legitimate.
articles.abstract: A court motion contends that Bernard L. Madoff’s investors cannot calculate their losses until it is determined whether any of their original profits were legitimate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bernard L. Madoff’s enormous Ponzi scheme ended on Dec. 11, 2008, when he was arrested at his Manhattan penthouse. But for some early victims, the date his crime started could matter much more than when it stopped.

articles.headline: Charges Detail Road to Terror for 20 in U.S.
articles.snippet: In an extensive terrorism investigation, officials charged 14 people who they say joined a Somali extremist group.
articles.abstract: In an extensive terrorism investigation, officials charged 14 people who they say joined a Somali extremist group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal officials on Monday unsealed terrorism-related charges against men they say were key actors in a recruitment effort that led roughly 20 young Americans to join a violent insurgent group in Somalia with ties to Al Qaeda.

articles.headline: News Corp. Weighs an Exclusive Alliance With Bing
articles.snippet: A deal to block Google searches from News Corporation content would erect uncustomary barriers and could scramble the landscape of the Web.
articles.abstract: A deal to block Google searches from News Corporation content would erect uncustomary barriers and could scramble the landscape of the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is not how business has been done on the World Wide Web.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Ashlee Vance

articles.headline: Iran Expanding Effort to Stifle the Opposition
articles.snippet: The government is launching an ambitious effort to discredit its opponents and re-educate the country’s youth.
articles.abstract: The government is launching an ambitious effort to discredit its opponents and re-educate the country’s youth.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria  After last summer’s disputed presidential election, Iran’s government relied largely on brute force  beatings, arrests and show trials  to stifle the country’s embattled opposition movement.

articles.headline: Right and Left Join Forces on Criminal Justice
articles.snippet: Joining forces with civil liberties groups, some conservatives say that the criminal justice system is a part of big government that must be contained.
articles.abstract: Joining forces with civil liberties groups, some conservatives say that the criminal justice system is a part of big government that must be contained.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In the next several months, the Supreme Court will decide at least a half-dozen cases about the rights of people accused of crimes involving drugs, sex and corruption. Civil liberties groups and associations of defense lawyers have lined up on the side of the accused.

articles.headline: Another Loss for Pfizer in Drug Suits
articles.snippet: The drug maker has been ordered to pay punitive damages to two women whose breast cancer was diagnosed after they used hormone drugs.
articles.abstract: The drug maker has been ordered to pay punitive damages to two women whose breast cancer was diagnosed after they used hormone drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pfizer has been ordered to pay a total of $103 million in punitive damages to two women who were found to have breast cancer after they used hormonal drugs, state court officials in Philadelphia said Monday.

articles.headline: Beware the Result of Outrage
articles.snippet: A proposal that would force a company’s creditors to take less than they are owed if a bailout is necessary could have the result of making credit harder to get.
articles.abstract: A proposal that would force a company’s creditors to take less than they are owed if a bailout is necessary could have the result of making credit harder to get.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest news story of last week?

articles.headline: Home Prices May Be Nearing a New Dip
articles.snippet: The modest recovery in home prices is beginning to falter, according to the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price index.
articles.abstract: The modest recovery in home prices is beginning to falter, according to the Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller home price index.
articles.lead_paragraph: Home prices are enduring an early winter chill, raising the odds that the economy may suffer another jolt while it is still weak.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Javier C. Hernández
